required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Juice Study: Sensitivity of Skin Carotenoid Status to Detect Change in Intake
clinical_study.official_title: Sensitivity of Skin Carotenoid Status to Detect Changes in Intake of Varying Levels of Vegetables

lead_sponsor.agency: USDA Grand Forks Human Nutrition Research Center

clinical_study.source: USDA Grand Forks Human Nutrition Research Center

brief_summary.textblock: This study is designed to see if drinking a tomato-based vegetable juice will increase skin carotenoids.

detailed_description.textblock: The US Dietary Guidelines for Americans recommends that individuals consume approximately 2-4 c of vegetables each day to reduce risk of chronic disease, but current methods for assessing intake are either inaccurate (self-report) or invasive (blood carotenoid levels). Recent research indicates that skin carotenoid status may be a useful biomarker of vegetable intake, but the sensitivity to dose in unknown. In this study, we propose to test the dose-response of skin carotenoids to consumption of 3 different levels of vegetable juice (with a control group receiving water). We will test skin carotenoids in two ways: using resonance Raman spectroscopy (RRS), which we have previously validated, and with a new technique, pressure mediated reflection spectroscopy (RS; the "Veggie Meter"). We will compare the two techniques during an 8-week provided tomato-based juice intervention. Skin carotenoid readings will be compared to blood carotenoid concentrations and single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) of genes related to the uptake, transport, and metabolism of carotenoids will be examined in blood and saliva.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in skin carotenoid concentration as measured by resonance Raman spectroscopy (RRS)
primary_outcome.description: Resonance Raman spectroscopy (RRS) is used to measure tissue carotenoids. RRS intensity can be used as a measure for total carotenoid content in the measured tissue volume.

arm_group.description: Subject will consume high dose vegetable juice daily for 8 weeks.
Subject will consume medium dose vegetable juice daily for 8 weeks.
Subject will consume low dose vegetable juice daily for 8 weeks.
Subject will consume control bottled water daily for 8 weeks.

intervention.description: High dose (13 fl oz) vegetable juice
Medium dose (10 fl oz) vegetable juice
Low dose (5.5 fl oz) vegetable juice

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- BMI 18.5-29.9 kg/m2
Exclusion Criteria:
- weigh less than 110 lbs
- currently dieting to lose weight
- allergic to tomatoes or vegetables
- pregnant, lactating, or planning to become pregnant
- currently use tobacco products or vape
- eat more that 2 cups of vegetables per day
- have high blood sugar (≥200 mg/dL)
- have high blood pressure (≥140/90 mm Hg)
- have a medical condition such as diabetes or high blood pressure
- taking medication that lowers cholesterol or triglycerides

overall_official.affiliation: USDA Grand Forks Human Nutrition Research Center

facility.name: USDA Grand Forks Human Nutrition Research Center

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: USDA Grand Forks Human Nutrition Research Center
